name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Show me your flowcharts and conceal your tables, and I shall continue to be mystified. Show me your tables, and I wonâ€™t usually need your flowcharts; theyâ€™ll be obvious. â€” Fred Brooks

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Sometimes the strategic breakthrough will be a new algorithm [â€¦]. Much more often, strategic breakthrough will come from redoing the representation of the data or tables. This is where the heart of the program lies. â€” Fred Brooks

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: TL;DR (continued): â€¢ Data-driven and lookup-table approaches are unreasonably effective at reducing the complexity of explicit logic and control flow. â€¢ The distinction between code and data is a casual one, not a well-defined one. â€¢ Code is configuration.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: TL;DR: â€¢ Changing representation can change our perception of a problem and a solution. â€¢ Refactoring is a process of discovery, sometimes gradual and sometimes with more sudden shifts. â€¢ Duplication sometimes exist at a deeper level than in the shallows we first notice it at.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @motto_meh I also use _ (and __) in Python for notions of privacy, but that's because they are recognised by the language (e.g., semantics of import * and name mangling of object attributes) rather than being an arbitrary external convention.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @dhkatz_ @benetsc I don't have a problem with 'is' used in a predicate, but I do have a problem with it being mandated as a prefix.  Other forms, such as the ones you show, are very clear, but sometimes 'is' is the right word, sometimes 'can', sometimes 'has' or sometimes a different verb form.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @B1tSmurf I always disliked this convention in Object Pascal. Noisy and unnecessary and no different to HN. Often used to cover up other issues with code and naming.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @sw1nn The use of single underscores to be an anon match is a feature in some languages and an idiom in others.  When used for parameters without language support, I'm not sure it adds much. Using it as a prefix feels noisy and often doesn't signal a quality that's useful.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @sw1nn It depends, and it depends a bit on the language and a bit on the culture.  If someone is doing this in C++, for example, they should reconsider. C++ already has this sorted.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I'm also picking on it because the idea that config files are a form of code is foreign to many developers; giving them citizenship is important.  And last time I raised this point, someone tried to tell me flat out that config was not code. Update: they're still wrong.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I'm picking on config here because it's a common source of problems, e.g., see Early Detection of Configuration Errors to Reduce Failure Damage   https://t.co/IzMLSvRNxA  And I find, personally, config clobbering is a common frustration whenever apps and sites update.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I'm not suggesting this as a permanent search-and-replace option, but as a thinking exercise. It helps to reveal blind spots and may highlight new possibilities.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Sometimes changing the words you use can offer an important shift in perspective.  E.g., replacing 'configuration' with 'code' may raise more questions of versioning and testing. Or replacing 'configuration' with 'database' may highlight that config change is a schema migration.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @AliannaFlynn @BronekKozicki A switch is a control-flow structure, regardless of whether it's a statement or an expression. For example, the following are all control-flow structures and have always been classified as such: switch, if, ?:, &&, etc.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @jurgenvinju That's a different solution style: it uses control flow rather than the data structure and flow of the Python version.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @AliannaFlynn @BronekKozicki Although superficially similar in layout, these are very different solutions: the one I presented uses no control-flow structures and is based on data structures and data flow alone; the C# solution is a nice example of pattern matching, but is based on control flow.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @pauldriveklepp Developers often overlook the visual design of their code. Many techniques and considerations used in graphic and web design are worth considering in the context of code. This is quite a good starting point:  https://t.co/F8ROaZGytz

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @pauldriveklepp The visual metaphor here is that of containment, and so the layout of the code should try to respect that metaphor, which is not done if you leave the enclosing ] at the same level as that which it encloses.

name: Kevlin Henney

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @bazscott Sand and soil are not as abundant in comparison. They are land-based and still have quantifiable scarcity. This would be like taking existing availability of soil and sand and scaling it by a few orders of magnitude ğŸ™ƒ

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: That said, if the cost of extraction could be significantly reduced, or written off, there is an opportunity here: such resource access could usher in an era of post-scarcity, which would simply defuse and undermine many of the asymmetries used to drive wealth and capitalism.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The cost of extraction is minor compared to $10 quintillion, but the market would probably crash long before the cost of extraction was recovered.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: To be precise, the market for iron and nickel would effectively cease to exist in its traditional sense if this much iron and nickel were introduced into the global economy.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Media outlets should stop sensationalising based on poor numeracy. No one with a basic grasp of economics believes the iron and nickel in this asteroid is worth $10 quintillion. Markets based on resources are not static when the scarcity of the resources change.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @IsdnMartin @DAbreu2018 @flyfishidaho If you like, this is taking the logic table implied by 'or'ing two bits together and using that table directly.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @IsdnMartin @DAbreu2018 @flyfishidaho Or, more concisely, in Python:  https://t.co/5g5mBsHUdM

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @IsdnMartin @DAbreu2018 @flyfishidaho My favourite table lookup approach, though, avoids the needs for a combination operation (+ or 'or') completely, fully committing to a tabular form by using a 2D array:  https://t.co/P8Y659kmsd

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @IsdnMartin @DAbreu2018 @flyfishidaho You can replace the use of an intermediate variable with a straight lookup expression: table[(n % 3 == 0) + 2 * (n % 5 == 0)]

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @IsdnMartin @DAbreu2018 @flyfishidaho Some might also quibble over the use an 'or' operation, even though it is a bitwise rather than a logical 'or'.  In this case you can avoid the issue altogether and just use addition, because you are only ever adding 0, 1 and 2 together, the use of 'or' rather than + is overkill.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @IsdnMartin @DAbreu2018 @flyfishidaho However, the C version you show has the problem of undefined behaviour: in line 8 a string literal is overwritten.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @IsdnMartin @DAbreu2018 @flyfishidaho Table lookups are one of my favourite approaches.  My favourite is probably the one that uses srand and rand:  https://t.co/hJscxHBqTz

tweet: @Jmason47 Using integers is a viable solution in a number of cases and, for the C++ developers in the group, would have been my recommendation.  The idea that decimal is a gateway drug to floats, however, feels speculative, and not a credible reason to not use decimal.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @m_mazur Yes ğŸ‘  My issue is not with the spreadsheet concept â€” which is expressive, powerful and accessible â€” but with how it's been realised.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @m_mazur Honeycode and AppSheets are targeted at (1), but most (not all) of the issues with spreadsheets arise because of (2).  I don't know enough about Honeycode and AppSheets to say whether they'll improve things or not, but I do know that some hype needs to be filtered ğŸ™ƒ

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @m_mazur There's two issues here which are worth separating:  (1) The effectiveness of non-code programming approaches for non-programmers. (2) Tools that contain known design and usability that increase incidence of errors.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @qmalvido Yeah, I think the truth value of "everybody knows how to use Excel" is on a par with the commonness of common sense.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @benetsc Yes, Excel is programming, but that's not the issue here: the issue here is that the tool is poorly designed for its users. As a piece of early 1990s UX, it's fine. But it's 2020. This one is on Microsoft, not the users.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @benetsc I don't have a problem with MS bunding Excel with the other Office apps. What I have a problem with is their refusal to address its flaws over multiple decades, a time frame that has seen them radically improve every single other application and system they ship.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @m_mazur "Will you please crosscheck and review my spreadsheet" is an uncommon request, as is filing bug reports with Microsoft or otherwise putting pressure on them to update and improve. Excel is the Coelacanth of office apps.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @m_mazur Although there is truth in that, I don't think that's as strong a factor as people make it out to be. The problem is it doesn't even occur to most Excel users to ask for help or for alternative options â€” not just software developers, data scientists, etc. but peers.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Most of Excel's behaviour is far from user friendly and shows a failure to engage with the users. It is riddled with faults that need to be fixed... like in any other software product.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: That's great, but in no way justifies or necessitates all the conversion-related flaws, the type errors, the default use of floating-point, the lack of visibility of data flow, the arbitrary limits, etc.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I have seen comments defending Excel against developers because it appeals to users and businesses use it. This misunderstands the issue.  What appeals to users is the openness, simplicity and flexibility of the grid layout for entry and manipulation.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: It's bad enough that businesses (mis)use Excel without understanding its flaws, wasting people's time and money as a result. Making life-critical decisions using such an inappropriate tool is the stuff of litigation and shows a failure to learn or engage expertise when necessary.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @idomdavis Yes, that leading zero is a quirk whose specific origin is unclear to me.  It seems largely to be a US affectation, but I don't know when and why it started. I don't believe digital watches or clocks in 1970s and 1980s are to blame, because those generally got this bit right.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @bodil The only thing that makes 12-hour conventions hard is lack of knowledge rather than essential complexity. In the Anglophone world people often assume they know, but it is the illusion of knowledge.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hmemcpy Yup. Don't get me started. I mention this in a number (sic) of my workshops, particularly where code examples include 'number' in the domain term... and still, folks will use something like int or long... and experience all the problems that were promised them ğŸ™ƒ

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: And the same also applies to names, telephone numbers and addresses.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I think it's worth spending (at least) as much time training and reminding (being a senior developer does not confer immunity) developers about date and time as we do on the quirks and representations of integers and floating-point numbers.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Just saw 0:25pm on a web page.  Although a spirited attempt to marry 12- and 24-hour clocks, that's not a legit time.  Date and time handling can be tough, but this isn't one of the hard bits â€” although it's clearly a blind spot.

tweet: @Daganev I'm not sure that's the case. The time scales we're talking about here are quite different.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @frzme I tend to compose my orders over weeks and months. And then find the additional login to be a stumbling block and annoyance and unsuited to my usage. Sounds like it should be configurable (cf. One Click).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @frzme Why is that good? If I shouldn't be placing an order, why does it make sense for it to let me compose an order?  If the half-logged-in state is supposed to address the problem of leaving unlocked screens lying around, then perhaps there is a better way of solving that.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Similarly, arbitrarily forcing people to log back in without giving them a sense that they need to in advance is another design blindspot.  Like borrowing a library book without a due date stamp (then changing the date). Give the user the information they need for their usage.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: This trend for websites to have a "kinda logged in, but not really" state â€” your user icon is shown, you can see your stream, but when you try to do something you get a "Ha, ha! Surprise, you're not actually logged in, so please log in!" â€” is a UX failure not a feature.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @blacksmith4life In other words, it's problem solving and collaboration, not potted answers, that have the value.  But that's not enough on its own, and so portfolios, blogs, community roles, etc. are important.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @blacksmith4life If the purpose of writing code is to show problem-solving approach rather than getting to an answer, then it has some value.  If the context of writing code in an interview is to do so with someone else, then it has some value.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @blacksmith4life My sense is most companies interview in a simplistic fashion that ticks boxes and superficially looks like they're after the 'best'.  Problem is that software development is generally not about on-the-spot performance or knowing the tricks, so we interview for the wrong skills.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @tinoprinzi That said, I did end up writing some flash that I was delighted with. Did so by entering a time-limited comp (NYC Midnight) and giving myself complete permission to step back and not do it if it felt too heavy. Some of the best fiction I've written in ages!

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @tinoprinzi I've written very little fiction over lockdown, but at the start, when I had more time, I found myself doing a lot of non-fiction writing. I.e., doing the thing I wasn't pushing myself to get done. Flowed more freely as it wasn't associated with any weight or blocks in my head.

tweet: @blacksmith4life Influencing culture (openness, mentoring, etc.) to bring about the changes in standard education and the acceptance of responsibility is the way to break the cycle.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @blacksmith4life Certification can make a difference in fields where there's a core body of knowledge and legal responsibilities; without these, certification can fall prey to market forces (a polite way of saying it becomes driven by money rather than need). Software development's not there yet.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @blacksmith4life I think more education (not necessarily by qualification) can make a difference. But there is a question of the content of education and what qualifies as a suitable core body of knowledge (the *BOKs to date have not been particularly impressive).

tweet: @ashtonshudson Humans are allergic to change. They love to say, â€˜Weâ€™ve always done it this way.â€™ I try to fight that. Thatâ€™s why I have a clock on my wall that runs counter-clockwise. â€” Grace Hopper

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @ashtonshudson There is a challenge here that needs to be acknowledged and embraced.  The goal of change and improvement is to introduce inconsistency. tweet: What is often missed is the more subtle implication that although more time is spent reading code than modifying it, the goal of the writer should be to reduce the time spent reading it rather than accept that as a given.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: One of the most important observations we pass on to others about code is that more time is spent reading code than modifying it.  We say this with the hope that it influences how they write the code, that they write with a human audience in mind rather than a machine one.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Not enough has changed in the four decades since Robert Floyd introduced 'paradigms' into the programming. n/n

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: "... and in the way our programming languages support, or fail to support, the paradigms of their user communities." Robert Floyd, The Paradigms of Programming (1979) 8/n

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: "I believe that the current state of the art of computer programming reflects inadequacies in our stock of paradigms, in our knowledge of existing paradigms, in the way we teach programming paradigms..." Robert Floyd, The Paradigms of Programming (1979) 7/n

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Many state models also don't require special handling or big support â€” just not switch statements. Coroutines, tables, class hierarchies, lambdas, function pointers, etc. These are suitable raw materials and are available in many languages. 6/n

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Programming languages and libraries have failed to offer suitable solutions in the mainstream. Sure, there's languages that do this directly, but they're niche. And yes, there's no end of homegrown state-machine libraries/preprocessers/etc., each one with its own quirks. 5/n

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: People rarely talk about the state model of their code, whether formally or informally. In many products it shows. They approach state and transition as a by-product of their code rather than its definition, regardless of whether they're thinking classes, functions, etc. 4/n

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Even in C, a big enum-driven switch is often not the best approach, so it's no excuse. 3/n

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: It's a failure of teaching. The switch approach is most commonly taught. All of the guidance on cohesion and coupling is thrown out the window, which sets a poor example. People learn from examples. 2/n

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: That in many programmers' minds 'state machine' equates to 'large messy switch statement' is a collective failing on a number of levels. 1/n

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @ejjcatx @nicksimpsontech It's also true many people conflate inversion with injection, hence common misnomer of describing DI frameworks as IoC frameworks.  However, passing arguments doesn't imply or necessitate inversion; there's nothing inverted about initialising an object with the state it needs.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @nicksimpsontech DI needs interfaces, but interfaces don't need DI. I've found that TDD and DDD offer better opportunities for role discovery and clarification.  If DI is what it takes to start people separating their code, then it offers a starting point, but it may be training wheels.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @AidanHarding Indeed, but I would go further: configuration files are code, even when they are simple. They may not be Turing complete, but they still use a formal syntax that changes the behaviour of a program. That's code.

tweet: @DavidTheWin I am generally cautious about the concept. I like passing dependencies (not a new idea), but dislike injecting them (the distinct centralising proposition of DI frameworks).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @nicksimpsontech I think it is. I generally prefer the alternative approach, historically known as 'passing arguments'. DI is a distinct proposition that adds centralisation.  Many people confuse DI with the idea of passing dependencies (i.e., arguments). The difference is passing vs injecting.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The design challenge here is not to convert runtime errors into compile-time errors, but to reduce the likelihood of errors while increasing the ability of the programmer to express their intent directly. This design challenge has not been met.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @vimalk78 Yeah, totally *crosses fingers behind back*

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: And of course, a note about RNGs: C++ has far more versatile random-number features than the rather rudimentary rand and srand... but, as this is C++, doing the simple thing is correspondingly harder.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Of course, C's facilities for time manipulation are error prone and significantly less than Gallifreyan in their abilities... but C++'s <chrono> overcompensates and manages to make simple tasks difficult and differently error prone.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The problem solved is not one of general time manipulation, but of seeding rand with respect to the current time.  The probability of getting this idiom wrong in C is low. The probability of being able to formulate and compile the corresponding C++ is, similarly, low.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @marvinirwin7 @asatarin If the 'getting' actually involves retrieval across address spaces, storage, etc., consider whether there's a natural opposite, i.e., a 'put', even if it isn't implemented. There may be a name pairing there, e.g., 'receive'/'send', 'load'/'save', that is more precise than 'get'.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @marvinirwin7 @asatarin If they are simply query methods, i.e., they basically represent the value of a field-based or computed property, then simply the name, i.e., 'foo', is clear enough.

tweet: @cratermoon Yup, I was tacitly excluding statics (which can be a source of fun and surprise) and inheritance to focus on the easy stuff, which is zero initialisation followed by field initialisers followed by constructor.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: So, not the most important question to answer in class design, and it doesn't have a decisive 'right answer'. What it does do, however, is reveal different mental models and weightings (I'd say 'bias', but that's not always positive) developers have around object initialisation.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @robsmallshire As you say, validation is a good example where this makes sense. I also find that common patterns of usage or calculated accesses (e.g., normalising an index or converting a value), which would otherwise lead to modest duplication, are also good opportunities.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @robsmallshire I always liked the idea of thinking about a class as a small program, so objects are small processes, and these contain a hierarchy (well, DAG) of functionality, which can include further data abstraction, even when we're already inside a data abstraction.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @robsmallshire I don't see enough of it.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @IAmSteveLove Yup, I ran out of space to add a note that I was only talking about 'class'.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The need to even worry about this issue is also reduced in the presence of certain other patterns and practices.  Immutability, for example, reduces the amount of code where this could ever be a question. But it doesn't fully eliminate it â€” mutation is in these languages DNA.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: This approach, of course, makes much less sense if constructors and fields are not close to one another, or a class is already a battleground of complexity.  Putting all the initialisation code into constructors is definitely a more practical choice.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: This leaves constructors the job of doing the things that field initialisers can't. In some cases, that's full initialisation of a field, in other cases it's populating a collection, which was already set up in the initialiser. And so on.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Doing so brings the fields and constructors closer together, making the reading easier. Conceptually the constructor scope is nested within the scope of the fields, so some consider them visually collocated and following an easy reading order.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: If we return to the question of the reading model, if the fields and constructors are adjacent, then reading the fields is part of reading the constructors, which is why many developers are happy to reduce lines of code to field initialisers when it is possible.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The normal way to at least bring some order to this is to distinguish between one constructor that does all the work and others that merely forward, but do nothing else interesting.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: In an ideal situation, we'd like everything in one place. However, constructor overloading also messes with this, so that to avoid duplication within constructors, people often use constructor forwarding/chaining. But this is in tension with having everything in one place.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: However, by creating such a strong syntactic distinction between fields and constructors, this puts these constructs and practices in tension. Another practice people like to follow is grouping, so having field initialisers and constructors creates a decision point.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Which also tells you why you leaving objects in invalid states for further init methods or property setting is considered to be outside of a good or valid initialisation habit.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: To follow the practice of initialising at or as close to the declaration as possible, leads to field initialisers in the cases where that is possible. In cases where that's not possible (fields depend on parameters) the constructor is the 'as close as possible' location.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: These various constructs have all introduced compromises and inconsistencies into practice (and the language) and none have ever fully reclaimed the directness and convenience of the closure model.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: This has led to different additional mechanisms added in to make the job easier/possible, e.g., member initialiser lists in C++, constructor chaining, initialiser blocks in Java (almost but not quite Simula).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: This separation meant that a special function (a constructor in C++, Java, C#, etc.) is introduced to perform initialisation.  Sadly, this function must be special rather than ordinary, because it's taking on the role of initialisation and is not simply just another method.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: However, later languages chose to make classes more special and lose some of the block-structured ideas. Ironically, this leads to a stronger separation between data and function (as opposed to a closer one, which is the normal thinking in OO).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: In Simula the constructor and field initialiser question never arises because there are neither constructors nor variable initialisations.  Declarations can't have initialisers. A class's statements do initialisation. There is only one way to create an instance (no overloading).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: A class could also be passed parameters to initialise instances. These were at the top, and were part of instance state.  In other words, an object is a closure.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: This is not simply a coincidental convenience: it's the history of OO.  In Simula-67, objects were simply referenceable blocks that outlived the stack frame. What can go inside a block? Procedures (methods), variables (fields) and statements (initialisation/construction).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Class scope in these (and other languages) is akin to block scope. The language design or way we are taught sometimes obscure the similarity, but it makes reasoning about classes, object lifetimes, etc. easier.  So yes, a field declaration is just a variable declaration.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: So, as you read from the top of a function/method/block/etc. you are introduced to names and values together, as needed, giving a cumulative reading model that is concise and easy to reason about.  What has this got to do with classes, fields and constructors?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Broadly however, the practice of initialising at declaration and declaring as late as possible offers more benefits than correctness in these cases, which is why the support for this is more widespread in languages now.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @Stuartq @ylorph Yes, I was careful to say field initialiser, which is common to both C# and Java, rather than object initialiser, which is the syntactic form you're referring to.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: In languages such as C and C++, which don't require control-flow analysis to ensure that variables are initialised before use, having a coherent initialisation strategy can be a question of correctness not just syntax. It's a case where the style really does become the substance.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: C99 loosened the constraint, allowing declarations to be considered as statements. I.e., it moved from Algol 60's model to Algol 68's model.  (Or, for the late crowd, it did what C++ and Java did.)

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: E.g., I found that many K&R and C89 programmers believe(d) declarations must come at the top of a function.  Such as restriction has never existed in C, which is a block-structured language, and variables to be local to any block, but required they preceded regular statements.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Another force that shapes habits is ignorance. Languages are complex, and programmers are often unaware of all the details.  In this sense, habits and style choices are formed based on mal-rules.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: It's important to recognise that many of our style choices are not made explicitly, and are based on habits we have never questioned, sometimes coming from older language versions or unrelated languages and environments.  Variable initialisation habits fall into this category.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Languages have at different times adopted different models. Older languages are more likely to (1) require declaration at function/etc. head and (2) not support initialisation at declaration at all.  These limitations have influenced many coding habits, regardless of language.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: As an aside, if you pursue supporting such a reading model to its logical conclusion, you arrive at or near the practice of not updating variables, i.e., a variable holds one usable value in one scope, and does not fishtail to other values. But that's another story.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: In other words, the reading model is linear and cumulative. You read from top to bottom and names and their values are added, rather than left unresolved or constantly changing.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: It is likely that many people who follow me do use this practice.  This practice makes for simple and concise reading of code. Ideas are introduced and fleshed as and when they are needed, and the mental model of state is rarely left pending or wrong-footed.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: A few weeks ago I commented on a tweet about variable initialisation. That still, in 2020, the practice of (1) declare as late as possible, i.e., just before first use, and (2) initialise at or as close to declaration as possible, was not as widely followed as it should be.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: But to better understand where the tensions are in the style choices, it helps to go back to the basics of initialisation, declaration, etc.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The question was about how class internals were structured, i.e., differences that make no difference to calling code, where you have a free choice.  So, interesting as builders, immutability, factories, dependency injection, etc. are, the question is unaffected by them.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Although I worded the question as unambiguously as possible, within Twitter constraints, and scoped it down to C# and Java (sufficiently similar in their initialisation mechanics) to reduce the noise, many replies effectively answered a different question.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: That said, the issue also revealed some interesting contradictions, which I don't think were resolved, and which were what triggered my question in the first place.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: A couple of days back, I asked a style question about use of field initialisers vs initialisation in constructors.  There were some interesting replies, some more considered than others, and where some insight into the style preference was given.   https://t.co/M54Z3hh6CT

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @SEGVeenstra @bouwe @Rene_Wiersma My question was framed specifically in the context of Java and C# for that very reason. I excluded other languages because other responses become muddled because of false cognate terms and wider differences in object models and initialisation.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @perlundholm The examples you present in your article are good examples of where builders make a difference, but there is absolutely nothing in the article that suggests this is the one true way to do all object construction.  That stronger claim is unsubstantiated.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @perlundholm Most classes people write and use don't need or benefit from builders. Some are fine with ordinary constructors. Some benefit from static factory methods. When builders make a difference, their use doesn't necessarily exclude other techniques.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @armigueddon Indeed. Although people have a system of approximations that make sense in conversational context, you won't find anything close to the nuance of that system in the if statements scattered through the code.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @thedrlambda @gaijin152 Continuations and callbacks are very much not like gotos ğŸ™ƒ  That said, you can use continuations to model gotos in a formalised manner. It's not pretty, though.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @Thorocaine If we take your specific example, you probably prefer a mix of relative and absolute, with less approximation:  (1) Yesterday / 1 day ago (2) 25 hours and 10 minutes ago (3) Yesterday at 17:45 (4) 17:45 13th August 2020 / 2020-08-13T17:45  I prefer (3) and (4) over (1) and (2).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @Thorocaine If I see something happened at 06:10, that is memorable and easily relocated. If I see something happened about an hour ago, then I keep having to adjust based on current time.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @Thorocaine Sometimes, such relative and approximate times are appropriate. But in cases where I am trying to differentiate and find things in a time series, relative times are less effective, and even less so when approximated.

name: Kevlin Henney

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @perlundholm A pattern is supposed to be applied contextually rather than uniformly everywhere, e.g., like the related smell of always writing factory classes. Using builders unconditionally makes code harder to write and simple cases that are better solved using other techniques complex.

name: Kevlin Henney

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Wild peeve: applications that show approximated relative times and don't let you choose absolute times as a presentation option instead.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Less domesticated peeve: applications that show approximated relative times... and then don't update them (making the unhelpful time indication even less useful).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Pet peeve: applications that instead of showing actual times show approximated relative times (e.g., "3 hours ago", "2 days ago"), which is next to useless for anyone that (1) knows how to tell the time and (2) cares about the time.

tweet: @perlundholm I don't think that's a very good guideline ğŸ™  Aim to make code simple and concise. Always requiring builders will have the opposite effect, making simple cases heavyweight and cumbersome.  Sometimes builders are the better option. Sometimes they are not. Don't require them.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @DustynEggers @mikeveerman All fields are iniatilised and, therefore, needed during initialisation. That's by definition of the language.  The case I am interested in is when a field can be initialised independently of constructor parameters and, therefore, independently of the constructor.

I follow the practice of initialising as close to declaration as possible. So if a field is constructor-parameter independent, I field initialise it.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @AndezFernandez They're not just syntactic sugar: they run at a different point, so they are semantic.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @mikeveerman The construction life cycle is (1) Default initialise all fields (to 0, null, etc.) (2) Run field initialisers (and, in Java, initialiser blocks) (3) Run constructor body

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @mikeveerman In these languages the role of the constructor is to complete the initialisation, not to be the only place that initialisation happens.  Why would you not use field initialises to do the initialisation that doesn't need to be in the constructor?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Question: If you are a C# or Java programmer and are in the habit of doing all your initialisation in constructors, rather than in field initialisers when you can, what are your reasons for not using field initialisers? Is it habit? Lack of familiarity with the feature? Or...?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @richardjwild Of course, if there is strong quality requirement that can be formalised, then it should be stated in tests.  Years ago I did exactly this for a hashing algorithm that was required to have a fairly uniform distribution mapping from 64- to 32-bit values.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @richardjwild I would expect review to clarify this, but I wouldn't write a semantic test unless I had a strong quality requirement on the hash code.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @richardjwild In the absence of a requirement for (1) backward compatibility with a particular hash or (2) perfect hashing, a hard-coded is semantically sufficient.  What this tells you is that not all qualities of code are necessarily conveyed best through semantic tests.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Given that years indivisible by 4 are not leap years, neither of the following claims can be made:  (1) Years divisible by 4 are leap years. (2) Only years indivisible by are not leap years.  But I see these in labs all the time, and likewise their equivalents in production.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: One of my favourite teaching examples is determining whether a year is a leap year or not (using a proleptic Gregorian calendar).  The difficulty people have in describing this accurately in tests is instructive.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: When we have made a statement about something that is required to be true, we have said nothing in that statement about what is necessarily false.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Of course, it is entirely possible (and likely) that the incorrect test passes for the values given, but this is luck rather than design.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: However, whenever someone has remembered to test for (1) (not common enough), I often also see (2), and not because someone intends a perfect hash.  This logical fallacy is "denying the antecedent". Basically, from "if A then B" incorrectly concluding "if not A then not B".

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: For example, one I see in production tests, courses and blogs is the following:  # (1) Given a == b then assert hash(a) == hash(b)  # (2) Given a != b then assert hash(a) != hash(b)  (1) is a requirement of any equality contract. (2) is only true for perfect hashing.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Logic is something humans struggle with, even (especially...?) if they're software developers.  It comes out in conditions in production code, but also in testing, so that conditions are tested for that are not necessarily the case, leading to brittle, overfitting tests.

tweet: Sometimes the data structure in question has a mini-language as its front end, such as regular expressions:   https://t.co/tza4qMw1cf  https://t.co/USxRKe1miU  https://t.co/mboBInFrTB

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Simpler still is finding a data structure that does the work for you:  new TreeSet<>(listOfWords)

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: A pipeline simplification, using Java streams, is simpler and more declarative:   https://t.co/Jop4ec2ZBW().sorted().distinct().collect(toList())

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: For example, to present unique words in sorted order from a list of words by hand in Java...

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Another often overlooked opportunity to reduce explicit control flow is in the use of data structures. Matching a data structure to the problem can make a solution simpler and more declarative.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: For example, the error in the following code (and in its 'incorrection') is easier to spot when expressed as a pipeline than as raw control flow:  From here:  https://t.co/HwELygSzxK To here:  https://t.co/d4MGvJZdrZ

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Control flow that is encapsulated and parameterised by higher-order functions/blocks/etc. or that exchanges sequential control flow for sequential data flow tends to be easier to reason about. And the jumpy (or less sequential) the control flow, the harder it becomes.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: What's often overlooked is control state and the implicit and explicit tracking of state in imperative control flow.  The more you need to run a program counter in your head and track changes and roles across variables, the greater the complexity, the more likely errors become.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: When talking about reducing mutability of state in imperative code, most of the focus tends to be on objects and the explicitly represented data and variables themselves, i.e., reduce incidence and possibility of assignment, eliminate methods with side-effects, etc.

tweet: @matthewpskelton @c_combe @TeamTopologies Yes, that's a good example.  Without knowing more about Slack's set-up, my feeling is that this might not be the case here because of other key aspects of the UX that ignored (e.g., the failure to decouple accounts from workspaces).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @c_combe @TeamTopologies @matthewpskelton Indeed. That would be one of the questions to answer. There are all kinds of hypotheses that fit these observations, so it's good to have a set of theories to test against.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: This suggests different teams or, at least, different people touching code and UI at different times, but without reviews across roles/teams. Possibly a PO or marketer who has a strong opinion on something, but lacks the attention to detail or humility to have something reviewed.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: E.g., in Slack, the profile sidebar says 'Add a title', whereas the 'Edit your profile' dialog says 'What I do', which is not the same thing â€” one is a title and the other a description. The switch to first person is also inconsistent with all the other entries.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: You can ask a lot of questions about a software product organisation based on the little inconsistencies across their UX. Sometimes these hint at questions of reviewing and cross-reviewing (or lack of). Sometimes these suggest organisational boundaries leaking through the UI.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: My comment was inspired by the number of times I struggle to hear people with bad connections and dodgy microphones when running courses, workshops and meetings. It's clear they're using whatever worked for them pre-pandemic, but have not otherwise been provided for.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: These are difficult times, but employers should be supporting employees working from home by paying for better connectivity and equipment. It's reasonable for the employee to demand this of the employer, not the other way around.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @natpryce Yeah, that's my favourite facepalm design decision. Never get a Python programmer to help you reverse into a space:  "Yes, keep going... you're good... keep going..." *crash* "OK, now you can stop!"

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @robsmallshire @natpryce Just to clarify, are you saying that a race condition is an error condition or is not an error condition?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @robsmallshire If there's nothing there, then that's the most obvious thing to return, but other options are available. Searching is a request with two normal outcomes.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @AlexLukbe The list could get long, but let's just start with two decisions:  (1) Use exceptions only to signal erroneous conditions.  (2) Provide expression-level exception handling, not just statement-oriented constructs.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @Tekay37 Consider list where remove and index raise exceptions for non-exceptional conditions.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @robsmallshire The two I've already been reminded of this morning are removing an item from a list and locating the position of an item in a list.  Absence can be considered an error condition when indexing, but is a perfectly normal outcome when searching.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I guess there was an opportunity to address this in Python 3, but it was either a blind spot or considered a minor rather than major inconvenience.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: If Python had a really good exception handling model, that would be less of an issue, but it doesn't â€” it's not bad, just adequate â€” which makes code that should be simple and brief, clunky and error prone. In other words, not Pythonic.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: It's present and abused all the way from the core language and into the libraries and, therefore, into people's programming habits.  The use of exceptions to chastise normal conditions reduces the brevity and simplicity of code.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Python is a great language and has made some really good decisions when it comes to consistency and simplifying usage.  But one aspect I have always considered flawed and at odds with the simplicity of what is considered Pythonic is the excessive love affair with exceptions.

tweet: @Tacsiazuma @omgzen Assert only on what's necessary and exclude what is unnecessary, otherwise you are likely to end up with overfitting tests. tweet: @smurthys @m_larsson My experience is that most constants are not, and they rarely have any business being global. Most constants should be local and private to a module or class, replaced by parameters or replaced by methods. There should be relatively few constants with global reach.

tweet: @tom_a_r_johnson Perhaps it's a reflection of how I was taught numerate subjects: the phrase "necessary and sufficient" was used often â€” possibly more than was necessary ğŸ™ƒ

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @codingsafari Hence my observation. I see this repeated often, but practised less often than I would hope.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @gennaro_prota Sadly, there's no shortage of performance myths and superstitions used to support questionable practices.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @davenicolette An interesting observation. My observation and experience of this is almost exactly the opposite of what you are stating!  Most of the languages supported on mainframes and minis were procedural and tended not to support narrow scopes and early initialisation.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @tom_a_r_johnson Yup, your reading is correct: use field initialisers rather than introduce unnecessary constructors. Using field initialisers when constructors are unnecessary allows more locality and avoids invalid states.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @bellinghman ğŸ‘

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: In this vein, another one I see quite often is the failure to use nested scopes to their best advantage.  Encapsulation is a broader concept than a private veneer on fields: it's about hiding irrelevant detail, including the nesting of types that shouldn't be top level or public.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: In one sense, there is one underlying idea here that manifests as a variety of more specific guidelines, ranging from information hiding to initialisation to code size.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The idea of locality is key here, and the more of it you have, the fewer surprises and less up-and-down scanning of the code you need.  This is intimately bound up with the idea of having the smallest scope/access, which also gives rise to the idea of small functions/classes/etc.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I also think that there is a failure to understand how this applies in general.  For example, many who would say they follow the guideline, introduce unnecessary constructor code instead of using more direct field/member initialisers.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I wonder how much of this is a question of education and guidelines (the point is not made or examples are not given), and how much is people learning osmotically by the example of the codebases they work on (which perpetuates the habit).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: For languages where it makes sense, a coding guideline I have encouraged for *mumble* years is declaring variables as late as possible and initialising them as early as possible.  I see this repeated often, but I still see far more code where this isn't applied than where it is.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @frederikheld That sounds architectural. Architecture can be considered the set of significant decisions shaping the structure and costs of change of a system. Some of these decisions are made by management, not by developers. Many in development miss this inevitable consequence.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @thinkfoo I think it is a common misunderstanding that architecture is about grand choices. It is best considered as choices that are significant, but these are not always either grand or deliberate.  Likewise, technical debt is also often inadvertent rather than deliberate.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @apcrft See my previous thread on this topic:  https://t.co/t0O4dVUJw2

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @jhumelsine @apcrft Debt is not always a positive thing, even in the topsy-turvy world of finance. @martinfowler's technical debt quadrant carefully distinguishes between the state of debt and the intention and context that surrounds it:  https://t.co/qevwGDfqPb

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @mbohlende It is important to distinguish between 'should' and 'is'.  When I state that it is 'often a decision made neither explicitly nor consciously', I am describing the world as it is, not as I would like it to be.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @alexbunardzic @davenicolette To be clear: I'm not talking about preferences. I'm talking about the world as it is, not as we'd like it to be.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Keeping technical debt is an architectural decision. And, like most architectural decisions, it is often a decision made neither explicitly nor consciously. It is often an emergent property of circumstance, which can make it border on invisibility.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @JRPerfetto Otherwise, keep generating the ideas and looking at your options, and do enough that you actually enjoy, but give yourself permission to take a break.  I don't know if that helps at all, but those were the initial thoughts that came to mind.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @JRPerfetto Doesn't matter. This is the ideas stage. And you don't have to back only one. Follow a course, submit your CV, catch up on DIY... all these can be done concurrently, and one will help the other. Then, when something looks like an idea you might go with, turn up the dials on that.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @JRPerfetto Giving yourself that permission makes it easier to be creative. When that starts, list off ideas, crazy and conventional, about things to do next. Look the same kind of work? Look for something in a different direction? Spend time reading/watching on new tech/approaches? Hobbies?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @JRPerfetto Just breathe and ignore the world of work for a couple of days. Hard to do, but giving your self some space to step back is probably the best thing to do.  Once you've decided to not focus on it, either your brain will come up with ideas or it will give more space to wind down.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @johnazariah And it's a perspective I don't see around as much, i.e., an array as int â‡¸ T. This useful perspective seems largely ignored by languages these days, which chose to separate using different syntax (e.g., [] vs ()) rather than unify around the idea that a function is mapping.

tweet: @johnazariah Reading the second post:  https://t.co/fU1w1OqKWz  I was reminded of the variety of approaches available to talk about arrays. It's become conventional to start from the position of them being parametric types, but considering them as functions offers a different perspective.

tweet: One of the most useful inclusions (but most common omission) on software architecture diagrams is teams.  Show relationships between people and software, not just software structure.  Architecture is a socio-technical construct, but we often focus on the technical in isolation.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @mjpt777 @tweeshan What's interesting to note about pipe+filter architectures is they're easy to reason about (i.e., get right) because they use sequences in two ways:  (1) components have sequential control flow (2) components are joined by sequential data flow

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @mjpt777 @tweeshan And, importantly, each stage/filter/transform/process can be sequential in its internal control flow.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @Neppord Indeed. Although async/await reduce threading explicitness, I am a little wary of them because they are raw control-flow structures, and given that the problem we are trying to solve is control flow, I don't think it's necessarily best solved using more control-flow structures.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @qmalvido Indeed, it makes a much better job of it than Java. I just wish it finished the job :-/  Overall, I think it's quite a nice procedural language, and it's introduced many programmers to non-thread-oriented concurrent programming.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @dmlled @qmalvido Unbuffered channels, however, are a problem rather than a solution.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @dmlled @qmalvido One of the first things anyone ever does with a high-level construct is emulate a low-level construct.  Tony Hoare showed how to create semaphors with channels in CSP, for example.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @qmalvido Of course, but relying on good practice is not a language feature.  If following good practice were that simple, I guess I would be out of a job ğŸ˜

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @dmlled Nice. University of Kent have a long and solid background in concurrency. IIRC, they did a lot of stuff with occam.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @zxq9_notits @FelixPetriconi Indeed. It is why I recommend a virtual uniprocessor approach (of which actors are a subset), i.e., the idea that any piece of code perceives only a single thread, regardless of the underlying concurrency of the system.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @FelixPetriconi I remember trying to encourage (and wrote a proposal for) higher-level (i.e., executors and futures as the lowest level) constructs for C++0x, rather than the lower-level Boost.Thread model that was preferred.  (And, as history shows, I was unsuccessful ğŸ˜•)

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @FelixPetriconi As an aside and historical note, I do wish that we were better at learning, teaching and introducing higher-level constructs rather than doing for threads as the first port of call.  It would benefit both runtime and developer performance hugely.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @FrancescoC @shoecatladder s/avoid/reduce/

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @Neppord It's a sliding scale.  An absence of other activity flows is the simplest (but not always possible â€” working around it can make things more complex).  Abstracted and encapsulated constructs (actors, async ops, channels, etc.) are the next most desirable.  Threads are the least.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @Thorocaine Nice. But still more subtle than code without. That doesn't mean these aren't good features (they are), and that they aren't better for developers and code than raw threads (they are), but sometimes the comparison to make is against code without threads rather than with.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @mysteryjeans The question is not what era I am from, but what era most code is from. There is far more code (being) written using threads than with constructs such as async/await.

tweet: So, a nice enough idea, and great to see this kind of progress, but don't hold your breath for widespread adoption or meaningful productivity improvements IRL.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Developers will tend to trust code generation without checking it. The generated code, however, needs more checking than equivalent code written by a human.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: By taking away the easy parts of the task, automation can make the difficult parts of the human operatorâ€™s task more difficult. â€” Lisanne Bainbridge

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Any automation that is reliable (but not 100%) runs into the automation paradox. People tend not to pay attention and will miss where they need to intervene. They will also become less able to intervene.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Of course, the assumption is that the developer will check the generated output to see that it is what it should be.  It is instructive to look at the history of automation to understand where this is effective and where it is problematic.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The newest computer can merely compound, at speed, the oldest problem in the relations between human beings, and in the end the communicator will be confronted with the old problem, of what to say and how to say it. â€” Edward R Murrow

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The generator depends on comments that are well written, accurate and precise.  This is not a hurdle: it's a showstopper. Understanding is the bottleneck in development, not typing.  Being able to precisely articulate what we mean in natural language is non-trivial.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Let's explore some (not all) of the issues that this is going to collide with in practice...

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @bartlettstarman Ideal situation: an invalid fixture results in an exception. Next most ideal situation: the exception thrown by the method of interest is unrelated to the one you're expecting.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @bartlettstarman Yes. False positives are not an uncommon problem. With integration tests, this is more likely (because externals are more likely to fail for reasons unrelated to correctness of code or test). With unit tests, it's often a typo, a thinko or an oversight.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @prdoyle @pryszkie @mistydemeo I think this is a misrepresentation of both OO and FP. Lambdas, closures, etc. are not unique to FP. name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @GrzegorzKocjan Experienced this with a framework team many years ago. One complaint they had was that application teams weren't taking full/'correct' advantage of the framework... but one of the requests from the application teams was to provide more reference examples.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @GrzegorzKocjan I have heard stories of many framework, library and infrastructure authors being surprised at misuses, only to discover that what people have followed is the intro examples rather than the detailed reference documentation.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @GrzegorzKocjan I think it's a natural consequence of how people are primed and imprinted. As humans, we naturally learn by example, and it's a difficult thing to turn off.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: In other cases, object internals are exposed because someone picked up the mistaken belief that constructors shouldn't 'new' other objects ğŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸  They've taken a poorly articulated idea and perfected it into an art form free of encapsulation and simplicity.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: In many cases, it is possible to simply replace the provider with the value the code needs, i.e., rather than pass the supplier of the value, pass the value.  This is reversion of control. Simple to write, simple to read, simple to test. Loosely coupled. No injections needed.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: We've ended up with a culture of injection, with code spending its time shooting up, passing providers, suppliers, factories, etc., leading to much foolish mockery and XML noise.  Code and developers have been cargo-culted into practices that avoid actually writing functionality.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @tom_a_r_johnson Both spies and mocks track interactions, and both may also stub. Classically, mocks have expectations set on them, and so are active in asserting expected outcomes. Conventionally, spies are passive in this respect.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @Rene_Wiersma I normally recommend starting with @martinfowler's post on "Mocks Aren't Stubs":  https://t.co/zSrCe1lvR7

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The gratuitous complexity of many mockish tests is testament to the human condition and blind spots in thinking.  Developers invest more time figuring out how to stub problem code, creating tests more complex than the code being tested, than in simplifying the code being tested.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @tom_a_r_johnson Indeed. And, strictly speaking, mocks in Mockito are spies... and so are spies.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @ayz3mbedded That, unfortunately, is the problem. They should lead with mocking: they are tools for testing, so they should focus on the goal of a test, which is the point of mocking. Stubbing is a trivial feature and much less important.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @wolframkriesing In framework contexts, I use mock (and mocking) to refer to superset of mock (sic), spy and stub, and dummy is a subset of stub.  Fakes are outside the scope of frameworks, but within scope of the process.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @wolframkriesing I tend to use the definitions from Gerard Meszaros, except when referring to mocking frameworks or the process of working with test doubles.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: My impression is that most tutorials on mocking and mocking frameworks lead with how to stub code for tests than how to actually use mocks for testing.  Such priming might explain many common misunderstandings around mocking, as well as the parlous state of many mock-based tests.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @HermanBovens @DanyBittel @kotlin Second, they should have put more effort to resolving the expression/statement tension in the language. The answer to that resolution would have benefited this case, rather than creating yet another WTF/FAQ. (Really, we should stop adding these to languages...)

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @HermanBovens @DanyBittel @kotlin Viewing lambdas as blocks (which is what they are intended to look like), the default return behaviour makes sense. So, first off, they should have simply called them 'blocks' not 'lambdas'.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @HermanBovens @DanyBittel @kotlin I've never seen labels used well for break and continue. There simply isn't a need. Including that idea was unnecessary. Muddling it with lambdas did not improve matters.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @HermanBovens @DanyBittel @kotlin It's a bit of a dog's dinner, and none of it is really necessary. It looks like someone got carried away with orthogonality and generality rather than looking at what was actually needed and what other languages do. Once they introduced labels, they were on a losing path.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @vhranger Although the idea of the testing pyramid isn't perfect, it does outline a better way to think about how to organise effort and get better feedback across levels of scale and connection.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @vhranger You're right to say that the idea you get better coverage of coarser units is an illusion; this is precisely why the surface area analogy you described is flawed.  That this illusion exists isn't a side effect of how units are defined: it's a consequence of systems and maths.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @zaphodikus @mpkhosla If I wanted to make best use of testing effort, I would distribute my testing effort across the testing hierarchy, from unit to system. If I wanted to make poor use of money, time and knowledge, I would focus only on system-level tests.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @codeslubber @allenholub The missing piece of the puzzle is testing, not contracts. Contracts make things explicit, but they are passive until activated.  The critical factor is the code was reused without being retested in the new environment. Had this occurred, the code would have been fixed.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Driving on the Right Side of the Code  "Taking a step back, we can see that, in its most general form, a test is a proposition about the execution of a piece of code or some aspect of a system."   https://t.co/aIdBPMOetF

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @codeslubber @allenholub I read the original ESA report when it was first published in 1996. I read a number of discussions and papers, including those from safety critical specialists. When Meyer published his piece, it struck me as lightweight and not really a serious contribution to the discussion.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @codeslubber @allenholub In the code had been written in C, the invalid conversion would not have triggered a failure condition, the superfluous subsystem would not have failed, the rocket would have continued into orbit.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @codeslubber @allenholub If preconditions were enabled, the code would have compiled, it would have been deployed, the precondition would have fired, the failure condition would have been unhandled, the subsystem would have failed, the rocket would have exploded. It would be identical to the Ada case.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @EversonME Some processes and approaches are more susceptible to twisting than others. SAFe is one of the ones that is more susceptible. Many orgs think they want to scale: they're often right, but often wrong about the direction â€” scaling down rather than up may be better for the them.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @EversonME Many orgs use an incomplete understanding of Agile approaches and hit problems. The problems they normally have are projections of the org. In other words, whatever process they adopt gets twisted into something else.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @EversonME However, many people mistakenly use it as if it were a specific process (and often they mean a degenerate version of Scrum). When I hear someone say "We're doing Agile", the one thing I can tell is that whatever it is they're doing, it's probably not Agile.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @EversonME In principle and in theory, yes. Agile is an umbrella term, a classification rather than a specific thing.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Even assuming that you're estimates are good, technical debt is not the cost of fixing; it relates to the cost of ownership of the debt over time. These are neither the same value nor the same concept. The difference between them is your motivation (or not) for 'repayment'.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I'm seeing a common theme across a couple of tweets at me about this, and they highlight part of the misunderstanding and faulty logic that surrounds a literal interpretation of the debt metaphor: the assumption that the cost of fixing is the debt. It's not.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @rifforama @martinfowler @KateRaworth Yes and yes. I follow her ğŸ‘

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @richardjwild This is true. The practice of enquiry, questioning and making a start on structuring what we do and don't know appears to have become de-emphasised.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @Tarrenam A bit of both. Or rather, I think both aspects may appeal, but often to different people.  It's one of those "it would be nice if it were true" ideas. It kinda wants to feel like a good idea, i.e., truthiness.  Others hope it offers an actionable message, albeit based on fiction.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kennybastani I can't argue with that: it's probably just as effective as other forms of bullshit ğŸ˜

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @gszabo91 @martinfowler Yeah, I've never bought that way of describing it (and I've had to do double-entry bookkeeping), which is why I don't use that analogy.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @richardjwild Oh, you mean the analysis and design phases? ğŸ§  Seriously though, it's the same issue. When people say they should have spent more time thinking about it, they're typically right. When they say they should've spent more time thinking about it up front, they're often less right.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @martinfowler It is the dismal science, but not all of it is bad science. As for numerology, that is more a property of economists and economic advisers than intrinsically part of economics ğŸ˜

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Today, found myself again cautioning against the category error of treating the technical debt metaphor literally and numerically: converting code quality into a currency value on a dashboard.  Don't do this. It's somewhere between numerology and bad science; economics it ain't.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @allankellynet Umm... that's part of the assumption I'm referring to (and what the solution addresses)... what assumption did you think my tweets were referring to?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Test Precisely and Concretely  "A test is not simply an act of confirmation; it is an act of communication."   https://t.co/kKo1DIp6OI

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @marick ğŸ˜†

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Setting aside time up front has diminishing returns the more of it you batch together. Spread the time across time, making the effort explicit if you need to (and you probably need to if you're in the position of having to discuss it).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: "The code would have been better if we'd spent more time on design," is something I hear quite a lot.  When developers say this, quite often they're right. Where they might be mistaken, however, is the assumption of when that extra time might be best spent.

name: Kevlin Henney

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @potetm ğŸ™ƒ

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @potetm It helps to distinguish between correctness and understanding.  A person may say they understand something, but have misunderstood. Another person would say of them that their understanding was incorrect.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @potetm In common usage, when someone says "I understand" something, they are relaying a belief. They are not necessarily communicating empirically demonstrated knowledge.  If you want to communicate something else, something stronger, you need to use words that communicate that.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @potetm This is why your code, your designs, etc. need to be communicated. That's where you field test, refine and clarify â€” for yourself and for others â€” your understanding.  The word 'communicate' comes from 'communicare', which means 'make common', and it is this meaning we want.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @potetm The confidence people have in their beliefs is not a measure of the quality of evidence but of the coherence of the story the mind has managed to construct. â€” Daniel Kahneman

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @potetm To write something that is understandable to yourself is far easier than writing something that is understandable to others. So yes, it is true.  But, to be clear, just because you understand yourself does not mean you are correct. That is largely orthogonal.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: success = talent + luck great success = a little more talent + a lot of luck â€” Daniel Kahneman

tweet: New blog post: Test Precisely and Concretely  Ten years on from 97 Things Every Programmer Should Know, I've revisited and republished one of my pieces on unit testing. I've significantly expanded it with examples in Python, C and Java.   https://t.co/kKo1DIp6OI

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hillelogram @themaxipaxi That is not to say it never happens... but in my experience, that the comments are a significant improvement on troubled code is uncommon enough to make it unusual and noteworthy.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hillelogram @themaxipaxi In most cases, unless another person is involved (reviewer or pairing partner), the author of the code will simply restate the code using the same mindset and mental model they had of the code in English. It's rarely an improvement.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hillelogram @themaxipaxi The issue has nothing to do with the expressiveness of English â€” that is part of what fuels the fallacy.  This is about the person who wrote the code, the understanding they have and the way they communicate that understanding.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hillelogram @themaxipaxi My most common objection to the claim of 'self-documenting' code is that the 'self' who wrote the code should not be the 'self' to make the claim ğŸ™‚  Making it understandable to yourself is, on the whole, less of a challenge than making it understandable to other selves.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hillelogram @themaxipaxi The issue is not whether people should have written comments or written better code: they didn't and, importantly, they wouldn't.  They worked with the understanding and tooling they had. It normally takes another 'self' to see the opportunities.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hillelogram @themaxipaxi Whenever I've been shown code that is commented, I'm always able to eliminate or revise almost all of the comments and find opportunities to improve the code.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hillelogram @themaxipaxi Whenever I've been shown examples of production self-documented code, I'm always able to find lots of improvements that (1) make it more self-documenting and (2) include opportunities for comments.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hillelogram @themaxipaxi In most discussions about commenting, 'documentation' refers to (3).  Is such documentation good? Not intrinsically or universally, no. Can it be good, yes. Documentation is not necessarily good unless the documentation itself is good.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hillelogram @themaxipaxi 'Documentation' is often used without qualification, but typically means one of: (1) Documentation produced & read externally to the code (2) External documentation that is produced from code and comments (e.g., Javadoc) (3) Documentation that is only in the code (i.e., comments)

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @fHachenberg â€¢ If we don't know what success looks like, it can be harder to achieve. â€¢ If we only know failure, we may end up accepting it. â€¢ If the situation is simple, failure can be helpful, but it may not be necessary. â€¢ If the situation is complex, failure isn't always a good guide.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @conways_law I think this is a hugely simplified and idealised view of the scientific process, so I would disagree with it as a representation of anything but an idealised model or as a convenience. As a model, I would contend that it fails to predict how science progresses and revises ğŸ™ƒ

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @andrewtraviss The problem is that that grain of truth is swamped by the more significant statistical truth that it is, in general, false.  If you rephrase it as "occasionally, the only failure is not to learn from failure" then it becomes true again, if a little less punchy.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @jezhiggins @fbuontempo @chrisoldwood @IAmSteveLove @DrVxD ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @cm_richards I would agree with you, except that I often see the literal interpretation wielded as the whole truth rather than a stepping stone to the truth or something that emotionally useful in a particular situation.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Likewise, "The only failure is not to learn from failure" is as free of truth as it is of the complexity that we find in real life.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: And the Bram Stoker quote "We learn from failure, not from success!" that I sometimes see bandied about is, to put it bluntly, pure bollocks.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Failure offers limited lessons, some of which can be valuable, but it's important to recognise that (1) just because something is taught does not mean it is learned and (2) failure offers more useful feedback in the context of simple situations than complex ones.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Similarly, the idea that "You learn from your failures" is generally not the case. Look at the world around you and you will see the majority of people repeating rather than learning from failure, or learning the wrong thing from failure.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: For example, "That which does not kill only makes you stronger" is statistically not the case, whether talking about mental or physiological trauma. Of course, there are exceptions, but these are exceptions and we love those stories, but can fall prey to survivorship bias.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: One of things we need to take care with is neat and tidy maxims that can be inspiring and motivating in the right context, but whose literal meaning falls apart under closer scrutiny. Without that scrutiny, we fall into some rather monochromatic and problematic thought patterns.
