name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @johanneslink @kittylyst A lot depends on figuring out what the goal is and who has the goal: Is a team employed to develop hardcore FP or to develop for deployment in a JVM ecosystem? The second is a more obviously real business situation, but there's certainly contexts in which the former may be legit.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @drewtarvin ğŸ‘ğŸ˜†

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst It's exactly the same issue. Which is why I didn't offer a definition â€” I only offered approaches ;-)  But one thing that is true across both cases (and many other paradigms) is that the type system is not one of the fixed or defining characteristics â€” which is relevant here.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst Java 8+, for instance, introduced features that would be at odds with dotted-i-crossed-t explicitness of Java 1's design philosophy, with Java 5 defining the first main deviation from that thinking.  What you are describing with `Object + foo:()V` would be in that vein.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst The point about LVTI is a good one. I was talking to some developers at a company in February and we chatted about idea that languages have particular design characteristics/philosophies that evolve but define eras, just as in natural language (e.g., Modern vs Middle English).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst Given that a language's design and context set up 'desire paths', the first approach would, I guess, be the closer and more 'natural' if Java were to pursue this line.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @davenicolette @GopalAkshintala The first principle is that you must not fool yourself â€“ and you are the easiest person to fool. â€” Richard Feynman

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @davenicolette @prepac No, it's not necessary, and it's not relevant to the point being made â€” although I suspect some may misinterpret that as the intent.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @davenicolette @iwasleeg Quite probably, yes :-)

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst @johanneslink And why Clojure has 'recur'. Given that Clojure is very FP and very JVM, I would say that TCO is not a critical defining characteristic. It may prevent some FP languages have a clean JVM implementation, but it does not mean the JVM can't handle FP as a concept.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @johanneslink @kittylyst @NewpPaul That said, as an optimisation, what is left open is when and how it's introduced: it can be introduced in the JIT, for example, or you can generate specific code to handle (some of the) cases.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @johanneslink @kittylyst @NewpPaul The problem with TCO is that it's a misnomer: if it were merely an optimisation, its presence or absence would make no real difference. But for languages such as Erlang or Scheme it's a necessary foundation, not an optimisation.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst Either way, type system is not a key or consistent feature â€” except, of course, to those who very strong views on type models :^) â€” so I would exclude it.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst We can do it intensionally by describing particular characteristics (e.g., functions as first class) or extensionally by enumerating languages that are considered functional, regardless of purity (the LISP family, Haskell, etc.).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst @NewpPaul The second point I'm interested in is the type of structural typing you have in mind? Are you thinking specifically of Scala, or further afield, such as Go or C (C is structural under the hood, but C++ isn't) or...? I suspect different challenges (and solutions) in each case.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst @NewpPaul My original point still stands: there are no JVM limitations or necessary extensions I'm aware of that hold back more FP in Java. That said, I'm no JVM expert, so I could be wrong.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst @NewpPaul The first point to acknowledge is this is a different question and direction to the original point: I was talking about FP in general, and Java in particular, but we are now talking about structural typing which is neither sufficient nor necessary for FP and does not define FP.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst @NewpPaul Sorry, meant to reply to this sooner, but it got lost in the busyness of the week :-/

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @GopalAkshintala Paradigms are like mixing desks, with many different aspects set at different strengths/levels. So an aspect may be more dominant and characterising in one paradigm than another, but it is rarely exclusive to a paradigm.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @GopalAkshintala Everything is not OO, but there are many things common to many paradigms.  Lambdas, for example, can be found across many paradigms, but they are not exclusive to FP.  This is true of other aspects, e.g., data abstraction, which is common to both OOP and ADTs.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @yaftu @kittylyst @nipafx @NewpPaul Having features in Kotlin that correspond to features in Java does not make it syntactic sugar.  Syntax sugaring is when you add  syntax that resolves to something else in the same language (e.g., Java's enhanced for loop is sugaring), while preserving the rest of the syntax.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst @NewpPaul I can easily imagine a Java-like language that is more purely functional that runs on the JVM. What I can't imagine is making Java that language.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst @NewpPaul I think the assumption here is that FP â‡’ structural typing and that such typing needs to be expressed directly rather than indirectly. Neither of those is the case.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @jakekorab If a system has no value, or is a liability, the question is not one of replacement: it is one of removal.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @girba ğŸ‘

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst @NewpPaul Why? What constraint do you have in mind? What FP model do you have in mind?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @girba Yes. Systems, by definition, are systems. A legacy system may continue to exist in spite of its lack of value, but because it is part of a larger business system, that larger system may compensate for the loss of value, propping it up when it would be better off gone.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @yaftu @kittylyst @nipafx @NewpPaul That first claim is clearly false â€” could you clarify why you think this?  And the second claim doesn't make logical sense â€” if a good IDE can make one language feel like another, why would the IDE vendor bother creating and pushing the other language?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @kittylyst @NewpPaul I doubt very much VM support makes a difference to the real challenges, which are to do with history, installed base, support, etc.  Clojure and Frege do just fine on the VM. Pure functional languages run just fine on von Neumann architectures ğŸ§

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @deworde No

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: It's not that a given legacy system necessarily isn't valuable. Maybe it is. Maybe it isn't. But it's not a given.  I often think developers, software architects, etc. would benefit greatly from courses on or readings in philosophy and economics.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: One claim I often encounter concerning legacy systems can be distilled as follows:  Legacy systems are valuable because they continue to exist; they wouldn't continue to exist if they weren't valuable.  The flawed reasoning becomes more obvious when stated like this.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @ICooper Indeed. I've observed the same relative truth in functional, relational, procedural, etc.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @cdpjenkins The ability to pass code around as an object, treat methods as objects, etc. There are foundational in OO: everything can be treated as an object.  The ability to chain collections and operation together is also a classic OO design idea, and can be found in Smalltalk, Ruby, etc.

name: Kevlin Henney

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @georgerball ğŸ™‚

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @GarthGilmour Adding method references (bound and unbound) would have been a good move, and very simple. Adding inner classes in that context would more naturally have led to lambdas that were, well, actual lambdas.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @prepac An interesting side-effect of more fully supporting FP would be better support for procedural programming :^)

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @prepac In theory, it could get there, but there would be little point or benefit in doing so. More worthwhile would be embracing the ability to support FP more fully, i.e., become a more obviously hybrid/multiparadigm language.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @georgerball Those claims are also based on misunderstandings.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @iwasleeg  https://t.co/ocbMqVNIih

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @prepac That is true... but there's still more to add before you need to worry about taking things away. E.g., being able to define a free function is fairly basic requirement language that Java still fails at.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @iwasleeg Indeed. The OO features added to COBOL (and ignored by COBOL programmers) two decades ago demonstrate this.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Sure, the addition of lambdas, method references, etc. means you can add light functional dressing to your code more easily, but proper paradigm support for functional programming in Java is still some way off.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: One of the most common misunderstandings I find about Java 8 onwards is that the addition of lambdas, method references, streams, etc. made Java functional: what these features did was make Java object-oriented.

tweet: @robsmallshire Difficult to say at this stage, and unlikely we'll be able to find out. name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Sometimes fluent APIs make the code, well, fluent. Clear and readable, capturing a simple narrative in a way that makes sense to the reader.  Sometimes fluent APIs make the code effluent. The call code ends up looking like the big unreview{ed,able} slab of text that it is.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @paulroho I'm not objecting to break it up, I'm objecting to what happens to the bits after it's broken up :-)

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: This messy habit, that some promote as "good" without ever having properly considered its properties, is also brittle in the face of refactoring.  If you want to make your code formatting messy over the long term, this is the way to do it.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: People who line up their parameter lists on multiple lines with the opening ( of the parameter list: stop it.  It's messy and inconsistent. Reading through a file is like following a drunkard's walk as the code meanders aimlessly around (and off) the right-hand side.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @janwilmans I consider integration testing to be code testing. It's code-centric. It's not about the software as used, but about testing aspects of the architecture integrated.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @janwilmans The distinction, and its consequences, is something we sometimes need to be reminded of.  For example, when we talk about testing, are we talking about code testing (e.g., unit testing) or software testing (e.g., usability testing)?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hanskruse @silverSpoon The substitution of 'y' for Ã¾ (the letter 'thorn', later written Ç·) is a consequence of printing.  Printing presses were not widely manufactured in England in the 1600s, so the letters available were those from countries whose alphabets lacked Ç·. The letter 'y' was substituted.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hanskruse @silverSpoon It is historical habit that words borrowed from Greek, such as Philip (from Î¦Î¯Î»Î¹Ï€Ï€Î¿Ï‚ / 'philippos' meaning 'fond of horses'), have Î¦ (phi) transliterated to 'ph' rather than 'f'.  The habit comes from the slightly misguided idea etymology matters more than contextual consistency.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hanskruse @silverSpoon Language evolves through borrowings, affectations and misunderstandings. The fact that the letter 'f' exists is irrelevant. This is English. It's a legacy system.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Two events in recent times have allowed me to improve the state of my inbox: the arrival of GDPR and the arrival of COVID-19.  They've been an unintentionally effective way to uncover which sites have my email address that I've either forgotten about or never knew about.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @conways_law My feeling is that communication needs to be, at least in part, visual. Words don't cut it. Verbal descriptions don't _show_ what exponential growth really is (the term has been devalued/depowered in everyday language) and what different scenarios look like over time.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @conways_law OK, I see where you're coming from (and going to). I was applying reductio ad absurdum to his position, i.e., dealing with the falsehood, rather than addressing the more challenging problem of communicating the truth.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @conways_law You don't even need to get that sophisticated. Deaths related to cars, smoking and swimming pools have R0 = 0. Their dependencies lie elsewhere.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I don't like to be so negative about a person, but spreading potentially life-threatening misinformation is cause to respond.  You don't need to be a doctor or statistician to know the difference between uncorrelated independent events and causally related spread of infection.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Dr Phil is a US TV celeb. Do we need to have the adult conversation about "don't take medical advice from unqualified celebrities" again? He's not a medical doctor and has no licence to practice.  It's clear from his example that he lacks a basic grasp of how infections work.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hanskruse It definitely depends: (1) Do the 8 arguments have interrelationships? If so, identify those types. (2) Are there common defaults? Should they be addressed by (1), by builders or by overloads? (3) If the record also requires the full 8, then it isn't necessarily the best option.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @hanskruse If your language supports only positional parameters, named parameters don't solve the problem :-/  Named parameters also don't 'solve' the problem: they simply accommodate a bigger definition of 'long'. Sometimes that is enough; sometimes it highlights a more entrenched problem.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @raspofabs As to why TDD is fun, I think it comes down to the sense of progress you can get from it, as well as an almost game-like quality it has to its structure. It is structured in a turn-based way, with goals to achieve, outcomes that are visible, while also incorporating creativity.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @raspofabs I think the taboo on fun is deep seated and comes from outside of software development. Business is serious business, so enjoyment and play don't sit comfortably within a culture founded on productivity and a simplistic idea of success defined in terms of money.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @codingsafari @housecor I'd suggest either duplicating the keys with a comment (the first entry, i.e., the comment, gets discarded in favour of the second) or, my preferred approach, give all comments a null key, e.g.,  "scripts": {   null: "Start the app",   "start": "react-scripts start",   â€¦ },

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @codingsafari @housecor However, adding a whole load of unused keys that are also valid path and protocol names may not be the most effective approach.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @codingsafari @housecor Perhaps, but perhaps for different reasons than the ones you had in mind ğŸ˜‰  There's nothing wrong with commenting something like a config file where you don't have control over the content and, therefore, can't rename freely.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: UI designers, improve your UX with another weird trick: avoid arbitrary constraints on characters in fields (e.g., allow dots in user names and spaces in credit card numbers). If they're not part of the domain and not programmatically hard to address, then don't constrain.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: UI designers, improve your UX with this one weird trick: if certain characters are not allowed in a field (e.g., prohibiting dots in a user name or spaces in a credit card number), rather than castigating the user with an error message, let the user know constraints in advance!!!

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @martin_rajniak (3) When implementing a class or function, consider what alternative implementations would give you the same desired semantics. Doesn't matter how impractical the alternative is, you're not implementing it, just using it to help see what is required and what is not.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @martin_rajniak A couple of things you can do here: (1) Other people: code reviews, pairing/mobbing and other discussion can help spot implementation-specific assumptions. (2) Tracking problems you've had in the past with this helps to highlight classes of assumption you might have again.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: If you're scared that the word 'fuck' is too disruptive a word to describe your tech, then you've learned something about yourself, your technology and the word 'disruptive'.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I've never been a fan of the term 'disruptive' in a tech context â€” it's business bullshit that has no place in your work.  If you mean to say "it's surprising" or "it's a bit different", find words to say that. If you mean to say, "this'll fuck things up", be honest and say so.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Hopefully the current situation will give people the opportunity to revisit some of the terms they use in everyday contexts, such as business or politics, so they can recalibrate and dial down on the hyperbole.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @robsmallshire @jwgrenning Yes, I haven't hit or explored the limits, so would be interested to know. I had 11 last week, but there were enough confounding factors that I can't be sure whether that was too many or not.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: In other words, aim for simple examples and, where you need something more complex, prepare as much as possible in advance â€” or go back to it later and revisit it and walk through when you've had a chance to complete it.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: And yes, unless your examples are sufficiently simple, it will be slow. No amount of auto-completion or IDE-fu will save you: all that happens is that it just looks more distracting as people can't tell what you're doing. The speedy automagic just becomes a flickering annoyance.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: If you are doing a full course, it may make sense to do a full live coding demo, but in many cases (especially for shorter sessions and conferences), resist this.  Watching someone else coding slowly can be as dull as it sounds.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: If your code is simple example code, with few dependencies, online compilers can be a surprisingly good option.  And, depending on what you're doing, they can be useful for participants as well â€” eliminates a large number of setup problems/differences!

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Use or create a distraction-free editing set-up. Large font size, no tools, different colours.  If you can work outside an IDE, do so (I find Sublime is just right for most needs).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Your normal development set-up is most likely to be entirely unsuitable for use when presenting: font size too small, poor contrast, screen cluttered with tools, build/pipeline filled with noisy output.  I see this all the time at conferences; it doesn't work there either.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: A couple of further thoughts on presenting code during a course/workshop/talk, some of which also apply more generally to conference talks.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @robsmallshire @jwgrenning ğŸ‘

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @robsmallshire @conways_law @jwgrenning Yes, exercises are a good natural break as they are follow different pace, have a different focus and are under the control of the participant.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @natpryce ğŸ‘

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @robsmallshire @jwgrenning Yes, start later for this (I started at 09:30 their time, 08:30 mine) and finish earlier.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @robsmallshire @jwgrenning Yes, very much so. I was wiped out last week.  If you can control the schedule as you've done, that's the way to go. Shorter days (much shorter, if possible), although I would recommend a full hour for lunch if you can.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @YvesHanoulle Find it or not find it, to be precise ;-)

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @YvesHanoulle It's good to have a timeout: I believe I know where my books are... but belief and knowledge are not the same. More than once I had to give up because it was taking more than 20s to locate. What I did in those cases was find it in the next break.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I may add to this thread as I remember more specifics that may be of use. Also, feel free to ask questions â€” I'll answer as best as I'm able â€” and offer your suggestions.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Not all courses and workshops will be suitable for an online approach, but I suspect this is something we are going to get better at!  My experience so far has me comfortable with lecture-style courses (e.g., software architecture) and coding hands-on style courses (e.g., TDD).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Recognise that not everyone can be present all the time and, even when in theory present, many will undoubtedly be second screening.  In practice, what this means is that recaps are more valuable than usual. Don't schedule critical info/activity for beginning of a session.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Take advantage of your unique situation. It's easier to show web pages you find useful â€” you're at your keyboard to start with!  But it goes further than this: I'm in my office at home, which means that when I refer to a book, I can grab the book itself and show it.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: I use this on my Architecture with Agility course â€” self-referentially an example of agility: you have a general plan, but your content is not fixed. At the end, participants have something they can go back to that reflects the experience they had, rather than a generic course.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Add your extra materials to a PDF that you update and share with participants.  This is a technique I use in some of my existing workshops/courses, where I update slides with photos of whiteboard content, plus extra links and new slides that are relevant.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Interactive exercises can be more awkward, so more careful scripting and preparation makes sense.  I normally use a whiteboard a lot. I switched to preparing slides for the things I would normally write out, and also using a stylus on screen to create hand-drawn slides.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Can be worth running a separate device as a canary to check what other people are seeing.  Definitely worth having a second screen, so you can share a whole screen that is under your control, and not just an app. Also worth using a headset and a mic.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: There will be connection and software problems. That is inevitable. Reschedule accordingly. Check back with people to see that everything's OK. They will normally tell you quick.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The client preferred to use Adobe Connect. So I did. Don't.  I was peripherally aware of this product, but I thought this was a legacy product from Adobe. Apparently it's not, but it's not one they're taking seriously, so you shouldn't either.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Stick to a schedule â€” the situational looseness you have in a classroom does not work as well â€” and take scheduled breaks of fixed duration. Use a countdown timer on screen.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: The course was supposed to be a 4-day onsite course. It was converted into a 4-day online course as that is the duration that was promised.  I would not recommend this duration. A 2-day course run over 2 days or 4 half days is kind of the limit.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Last week I ran a remote training course for a client. It went surprisingly well. Some things went well because of planning; some things went well because of luck. Some things went poorly in spite planning; some things went poorly because of luck.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @DeveloperCoppio I think you arrived too late: YAGNI is already out there. Of course, don't overdo acronyms [*] these things require context and explanation, but if you want to compare and contrast in a way that is memorable, draw from the same source.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @martinfowler I think it's (way, way) too late for that: YAGNI ğŸ¤”  Providing a precise and completely uncatchy proper noun phrase won't stick when the comparison is with a more playful acronym. Human psychology is the main force at work here, so like for like.

tweet: Boolean-to-Boolean converter: a piece of code that makes heavy weather, and extensive of literal 'true'/'false', to express a logical result.  E.g.,    return condition ? true : false;  Or, better (worse...?),    if (condition)       return true;   else       return false;

tweet: @cbeust @mariofusco @BrianGoetz @tagir_valeev @97_Things Optional is not an error indication. That's a common misunderstanding.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: For example, the common problem of typing into a text box used for incremental searching, and having the entry stutter or block because the "incremental" search algorithm is blocking it.  This is an elementary application of concurrency, yet so many sites and apps overlook it.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Software developers have a poor relationship with concurrency. They often shove threads in where they add more complexity than performance, and overlook the cases where it would make an actual difference to the user.

tweet: Minimal Groovy implementation of FizzBuzz using lambdas and avoiding retesting of conditions or state (ultimately inspired by Maciej PirÃ³g's Haskell solution).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: def fizzbuzz(n) {     id = {it}     val = {{_ -> it}}     fizz = n % 3 ? id : {val('Fizz' + it(''))}     buzz = n % 5 ? id : {val('Buzz' + it(''))}     fizz(buzz({it.toString()}))(n) }

tweet: Once again, experiencing that when a library/framework/product is described as having "a rich set" of functions/types/functionality, it's a euphemism for "an incoherent, legacy mishmash" :-/

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Sometimes I read or hear someone say that what a particular codebase needs is more documentation/commenting.  Be careful what you wish for, you may get it.  'More' is rarely what you want; 'better' is normally what you want. Don't wish for quantity when what you need is quality.

tweet: @helpermethod @maciejwalkowiak @ZanMcQuade @97_Things One of my clients, for example, successfully factored out platform-level concepts based on their stability (i.e., they didn't factor things out immediately, they waited to see the evolution). tweet: @robertfriberg Not necessarily. The applicability of this depends on the language and the kinds of collections and elements. But even then, it can still be a smell.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @markdalgarno Yes, there is a tension there. On that is resolved favourably in some cases, but can be a blindspot in others.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @simonbrown In theory, yes. In practice, however, List<Thing> normally means "We couldn't be arsed to think about what and how we are returning the result" ;-)  Set says something; List says much, much less and is not clearly superior to iterators, streams, etc.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @simonbrown Indeed. My default preference is for a means of accessing over an actual representation. That additional commitment may be appropriate, and I wouldn't exclude it, but I would tend to err on the side of non-collection access by returning a stream, an iterator or using visitation.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @simonbrown That's three quite different examples you've included, not all created equal. IEnumerable (and, by implication, IEnumeration) is my preferred approach, and is an alternative to returning any kind of collection. E.g., I would use IEnumerable in preference to Set<>.

That makes quite a difference to how you work with types, which partly sidesteps some but not all of the problems of type-level commitment I have in mind. name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @nipafx @deworde @yonatan_karni I enjoyed this piece when it came out.  I have run workshops where the question has come up and we've shown, by development, the limitations. Until immutability is a first class concept (hey, inline classes, over here!), any Java attempt at immutable collections will be limited.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @nipafx @yonatan_karni Sorry, that's what I meant: a stream instance cannot be revisited, but the stream can be reissued. Same as when solving this using an iterator. Single pass iterators have never been a problem here.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @bitsforthought You will find it's not quite as unified as that in FP. What does and doesn't get passed around idiomatically depends on the language. Which language did you have in mind?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @yonatan_karni @deworde @nipafx @vavr_io They're still collections. You still have coupling. You are still overpublishing. They don't solve the basic encapsulation problem.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @yonatan_karni @nipafx I am interested to know why consuming once is an issue. Surely you can just revisit the stream to create N aggregations, given that's what you would have been doing with the collection anyway?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @yonatan_karni @nipafx Mutability is one assumption that causes problem. Publishing type assumptions is another. In both cases, and even in the remainder, the basic issue is one of overpublishing, i.e., overcommitting in the interface.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: ğŸ˜®

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: And prior to Java 8 my recommendation was to return iterators.  And irrespective of language version, another consideration is whether the access should exist at all: Can the usage be reflected in the interface rather than just passing back raw materials?

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @yonatan_karni @nipafx I would say that (1) Consuming once is feature. (2) Most sensible uses of returned collections result in a single pass. (3) Many of the less sensible ones, especially those that alias and manipulate the collection, deserve not to be written and to be addressed another way.

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: Returning collections from fields as method results. That's about as unencapsulated as it gets (sic) while still using the 'private' keyword. Given a choice, don't do this. Consider collection return types a smell.

tweet: @lanegreene I was born in Brazil, but grew up in London. My father's family is part Irish (Kevlin is from County Wicklow). The English part came from Cumbria (Henney, which is a vowel shift of the Scottish Hannay). My mother is Brazilian: her maiden name is da PurificaÃ§Ã£o (my third name).

name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: First name's originally a surname. Isn't restricted as a male name (first other Kevlin I heard about was a woman). Frequently misheard, misspelled and autoincorrected as Kevin or Kelvin. Also often abbreviated to Kev. Sorry to Kevins, Kelvins and Kevs out there. Not a big fan.

tweet: @ericniebler @arne_mertz @incomputable @tvaneerd I think that forms a subset of the overarching style/era, but doesn't capture all or characterise the *now* of it. name: Kevlin Henney
tweet: @arne_mertz @ericniebler @incomputable I have taking to calling the C++11+ era post-modern.  The challenge with the word "modern" is that it both means C++98, policy-based design, etc. concepts and era and also means "now".  The same issue occurs with other uses of "modern", e.g., modernism in the arts is in the past.
